author: brycem
body:
The following new DRT tests ported from psl-monad DRT TTests are passing on Windows, but failing on Linux\OSX:

```
        It "should Set-Content to testdrive:\dynamicfile.txt with dynamic parameters" -Pending:($IsLinux -Or $IsOSX) {
            $result=set-content -path testdrive:\dynamicfile.txt -value "ExpectedContent" -passthru
            $result| Should BeExactly "ExpectedContent"
        }
        It "should return expected string from testdrive:\dynamicfile.txt" {
            $result = get-content -path testdrive:\dynamicfile.txt
            $result | Should BeExactly "ExpectedContent"
        }
```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Ah, can you try something:

We don't (yet) support backslashes as path delimiters (but it'll happen, see #570). So far our only use of Pester's `testdrive` is in the form of `Join-Path $TestDrive -ChildPath breakpointTestScript.ps1`. 

Does this error recur if you use that syntax instead of `testdrive:\dynamicfile.txt`?

comments.author: brycem
comments.body: This syntax for file that exists works:  testdrive:\$file1 - will try '(Join-Path $TestDrive -ChildPath dynamicfile.txt)'

comments.author: brycem
comments.body: Same error when using the join-path approach:  https://travis-ci.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/jobs/38205791

comments.author: brycem
comments.body: @andschwa I've reverted the work-around and went back to -Pending:($IsLinux -Or $IsOsX) for the affected tests for now.

on Linux we definitely need to see `/` and windows doesn't care whether it's `\` or `/`
